TITLESTMT.TITLE: A survey of the buildings and encroachments on the river of Thames, on both sides from London-Bridge eastwards to the lower end of Lyme-house: taken by the principal officers and commissioners of his Majesties navy, with the assistance of the elder brethren of Trinity-house, in pursuance of an order of the right honourable the Lords Commissioners for executing the office of Lord High Admiral of England, dated the first of March, 1683/4. Wherein is also particularly expressed which of the said buildings and encroachments are old, and which are new, and likewise which of them are judged most prejudicial to navigation and the river; together with references to each of them by numbers in the draught of the river lately made by Captain Collins.

TITLESTMT.TITLE: A survey of the buildings and encroachments on the river of Thames, on both sides from London-Bridge eastwards to the lower end of Lyme-house: taken by the principal officers and commissioners of his Majesties navy, with the assistance of the elder brethren of Trinity-house, in pursuance of an order of the right honourable the Lords Commissioners for executing the office of Lord High Admiral of England, dated the first of March, 1683/4. Wherein is also particularly expressed which of the said buildings and encroachments are old, and which are new, and likewise which of them are judged most prejudicial to navigation and the river; together with references to each of them by numbers in the draught of the river lately made by Captain Collins.

NOTESSTMT.NOTE: A list of the buildings on either side of the river from London-Bridge, eastward.
Reproduction of the original in the Guildhall Library, London.

DIV1.HEAD: A SURVEY OF THE Buildings and Encroachments on the River of Thames, on both sides, from London-Bridge Eastwards to the lower end of Lyme-house: Taken by the Prin∣cipal Officers and Commissioners of his Majesties Navy, with the Assistance of the Elder Brethren of Trinity-house, in pursuance of an Order of the Right Honourable the Lords Commissioners for Executing the Office of Lord High Admiral of England, Dated the First of March, 1683/4. Wherein is also particularly expressed which of the said Buildings and Encroachments are Old, and which are New, and likewise which of them are judged most prejudicial to Navigation and the River; together with Re∣ferences to each of them by Numbers in the Draught of the River lately made by Captain Collins.

TABLE.HEAD: On the South-side of the River, from London-Bridge, Eastward.

ROW.CELL: Old or New, and which prejudicial.
AT Allen's Dye-house a pott Gallery
Mr. Cholmley the Brewer, a pair of Stairs
Mr. Gibbs's Wharf on the East-side Pickleherring-stairs
A Pott Gallery upon the West-side of Still-stairs
A Pot Gallery to the West of Wheelers-yard
Stephen Matthews, alias Mr. Lewsley's Wharf
From the West End of Mr. Cundy's Wharf to the West End of Mr. Boddy's Yard
From the West end of Cundy's Wharf to the East of Philip Castney's Wharf
St. Saviours Dock, Mr. Veering's Timber-Yard
Mr. Heyden, junior, alias Collins's Yard
From Mr. Stephens's House to the Stairs at the West-end of his Yard
From East-side of Redriff-Bite to the West of Church-Wharf
From the West-side of Captain Bowers's House to the East-side of Mr. Whittingham's
From the Crane against Redriff-Church-steeple to the East-end of Slightfoot's House
From the East-end of Captain Wardlow's to the West-end of Farren's
Mr. Farren's Timber-Wharf by Russel's Powder-Mill
The Yard in the Possession of Sir William Warren is
Sir Thomas Gold's Yard, in the Possession of Grassingam and Collins
From the West-side of Rolfe's Yard to the West-side of Globe-stairs
The Merchants Plank-Wharf on the East-side of Globe-stairs
Major Bornes's Wharf to the East of Mr. Shishes Yard
From the Shepard and Dogg-stairs Eastward
From the West of Mr. Hunt's Gun-wharf to the West of Mr. Hill's Timber-yard
Next Wharf to Mr. Walraven's Wharf
Mr. Walraven's Wharf at the Sign of the Kings-Head
From the West-side of the Rape-Mill Westward

TABLE.HEAD: On the North-side of the River, from London-Bridge Eastward.

ROW.CELL: Old or New, and which prejudicial.
BIllinsgate, Smart's Key, from the Corner up into the Dock,
St. Katherines, from Iron-Gate towards St. Katherines Dock are Pot Galleries
From Mr. Butterfield's to Ship-Brew-house a Pot Gallery
Mr. Bullock's three Houses Pot Galleries
Next to him is a Bile about 8 Foot, in which shews all between him and Anderson to be Encroached
A Jetty on the West-side of Andson's and the East side of Fifield's Pot Gallery, by which it appears that those Wharfs and Buildings on each side of the said Pot Galleries are Encroached
From thence to the West of Mr. White's Launch
From the said Launch to the East-side of White's Yard
From Mr. Bradley's the Anchor-smith's Wharf below Wapping New-stairs to Mr. Snipe's House
From the West-side of King Edward's Stairs, East
A Causway from King Edward's Stairs
Sir William Warren's, the Old Encroachment
From Sir William Warren's to New-Crane-stairs
From thence to George King's, a Boat-builders Yard
A Lay-stall 3 Foot, and ready to fall
Mr. Denn's, alias Buzby and Joyce
Bell-wharf Brew-house, with a large Bite going in, Old,
Mr. James Ems Yard, from the East-side of the Launch to the East-side of the Yard
From the West-side of Captain Prestman's House to the West-side of Queens-stairs
Queens-stairs, Mr. Rich's a Shipwrights Yard to the East of Queens-stairs
From the East of Marshal's House to the East of Cox's Yard
Wats, an Oar-makers Wharf, East of Dick-shore to Mr.Graves's Yard
From the Crane in the Possession of Mr. Margate to the Stairs by the Biew-Anchor
Edward Gray's Wharf, from the Blew-Anchor to the East-side thereof

CLOSER.SIGNED: R. Haddock. J. Tippets. J. Narbrough. J. Sothern. Sam. Chamblet. Simon Nichols. Henry Teddeman. Thomas Brown. Isaac Wooodgreen. John Hill. Thomas Collier. Nich. Kerrington. Henry Mudd. William Green.
